reviews.review_text: Games don't scare me. Movies don't scare me. In fact, short of being dropped in the middle of the ocean or singing in public, there's not much I'm bothered by... except Amnesia. Why? Because in this game, I am powerless. I cannot fight back. Games like Doom, Resident Evil, Dead Space, etc.; They fail to send chills up my spine and make me squeal like a child because they made the mistake of giving me an arsenal of weapons and badass personality traits. Are Isaac Clarke and Claire Redfield afraid? Sure, and I don't blame them. But I'm not, because I look awesome and I can materialize various tools of immenent destruction. Those creepers waiting to pop-out from behind the corner aren't trying to scare me, they're sacrificing themselves to the God of Death! Amnesia, though... My tools are the world's worst lantern and a number of closets to hide in! I couldn't fight if my life depended on it, and it most certainly does. Well done, Amnesia; I haven't looked over my shoulder this much since I was 12.

The game that will make you crap your pants. At least I'd like to put it that way. The developers have always, in my eyes, succeeded in bringing a true form of horror. The Game offers an eerie atmosphere in a Prussian Castle where the main character Daniel awakes after he drank a mixture that'll make him forget, hence the Title. You will however soon find out why Daniel chose to forget, and let me tell you, you would've chosen to forget too. Without any means to defend yourself you're being thrown into a dark, creepy castle full of Horrors that may (or may not) lie around every corner. Was that noise you just heard your mind playing tricks on you? Or was it something far more dangerous. I wan't to be honest, I could barely play the game for longer than an hour without suffering panic attacks, intense amount of fear and dread and lots and lots of foul language.  if you're into Horror Games, don't let this GEM slip by. Many people said this game set the bar for Horror Games to a new high, rightly so. If you don't mind 1st Person and being defenseless, plunge into the minds of Daniel as he explores the Castle to find his true identity, what led him there and why he gave himself the order to murder someone deep down in the castle.  There are also a lot of Custom Stories that can be downloaded and played at the developers forums.  5/5, by any means. If you're a Horror fan and you haven't played/heard of this game yet, you shou-... MUST give this game a try.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of those games that only comes around once all of the planets in our solar system align perfectly - which, is to say, never. But yet Amnesia did come around, and it redefined not just the horror genre itself, but indie gaming as a whole, I think. It showed that first-person gaming fit the horror experience perfectly (in my opinion, even demonstrating that first-person horror is the best possible kind of horror), and with the right narrative and thematic techniques (in both writing and gameplay), could create a rich and beautifully dark universe for the player to inhabit.   ... Assuming the player actually is bad enough to launch the game in the first place, that is. There's no two ways about it: Amnesia is one of the most terrifying games ever created, and that's as much a byproduct of its powerful and compellingly grim story as much as it is a byproduct of its grueling and sinister gameplay. At points you will be overwhelmingly afraid to continue playing, simply because every action and every moment you spend interacting with it, you realize more and more how powerless and incapable you are, and how little resources you really have. There is no combat in Amnesia - there is only survival, and it's as fleeting as it is difficult.  It's not the game for everyone, but I think that all gamers should at least try to experience it; even the first half of it, if not more. It may take you months to accomplish, but a full playthrough of Amnesia can be one of the most rewarding and exhilarating experiences in the history of gaming.

This a game from the time when horror games required more than just a defenseless protagonist and some strobe lighting (machine for pigs I'm looking at you).   +Looks great (espesially lighting) +Is actually scary without having many jumpscares +The physics engine is fantastic +Sounds are the best of the best and same goes for the music +Difficulty: it's far from a walking simulator (amfp :P) but the monsters are actually very easy to avoid and they are there just to keep the game interesting +Sanity system and limited light resources ±The story is ok, but it's told in paper notes so be ready to read alot. If you are spotted, they will chase you for couple of seconds and lose their interest at the same second they don't see you anymore. Most of the time I get solid 60fps, but in some large areas I get some very annoying drops. Mostly lag spikes fortunately, nothing gamebreaking  In conclusion this is a very solid horror game that has some truly freaky moments. The main story alone doesn't last for too many playthroughs, but fortunately there is still an active mod community. I'd recommend to download at least Study of insanity and Black forest castle. I was gifted this game off of a friend after viewing some playthroughs and expressing my interest in trying to play the game myself, and needless to say, I didn't find myself disappointed. Just as I believe the creators of Amnesia wanted, the game was atmospheric and compelling from start to finish. What I have in high regard about this game is the use of wit to survive rather than fighting skills, alongside it's several small puzzles and memory trips that added to the game. As for the actual gameplay itself, the entirety of the game ran smoothly and was more than easy to get to grips with, although I was stupid and didn't actually realise you could sprint until over halfway through the game (its Shift + W by the way.) On the contrary, the only thing I'd personally alter about this game is the detail of the storyline and lack of interaction. I'm aware that the isolation of the games main character is what adds to the atmosphere, but some kind of interaction would've made the storyline a lot more interesting for me, rather than a dozen flashbacks and lengthy notes/diaries. As a person who enjoys progression in a game a lot more than having to read long-winded notes and excerpts, I feel as though this would've been what could of made the game for me, but that's a matter of opinion. Either way, the storyline is easy enough to understand without reading a single note anyways, which is a good plus to the game. I found that generally, Amnesia's story was somewhat fascinating and original, but the normal ending that I had experienced was a little disappointing after 11 hours of gameplay and not as intense as I'd of expected. Whilst a few things let me down within the game, these are all minor/opinions, and there is nothing legitimate at fault. I'd recommend this game as a must-play for any horror fan to try out at least once.

The infamous Amnesia. Driven by a dark and twisted storyline, backed by a soundtrack that is bound to give you the chills, Amnesia is everything you could ask for in a horror game.  Introduction: Amnesia is a first person survival horror game set in a dark and mysterious castle environment. The plot takes place in 1893 where a young man from London, Daniel, finds himself awakened in the great halls of the Prussian Brennenburg Castle with no recollections of himself, his past or his current purpose. The only objects that guide Daniel in his journey are hand-written notes that he has written to himself, such as the one he finds in the beginning of the game.   Controls and Gameplay: The most powerful feature in the game is the absence of items, such as weapons and armor. You are alone and defenseless. Only equipped with a lantern, run by a limited supply of fuel, your goal is to explore and uncover the dark secrets of castle Brenneburg. This is a core feature of the game, as it makes your journey through the castle perilous and terrifying.  Aside from the traditional health bar, your character has a sanity meter. Sanity is reduced if you spend too much time in the dark, and loss of sanity will progressively make your screen indistinct and blurry.   Puzzles and other obstructions are also present in the game. They are, however, not difficult and are sometimes a more than welcome 'time-out' in the intense horror, while at other times they participate in making the game more hectic and intense.   In terms of control, they are working as intended and do not obstruct the player in his quest through the dark.  Graphics: The graphics in the game are slightly dated. This is not a huge minus, as the graphics actually enhance the intense sensation of dread that is omnipresent in the game.   Sound: The soundtrack subliminally emphasizes the mood of the game. It intensifies frightening moments and sooths you in safe zones. It sometimes disappears completely, leaving your character's frantically beating heart as the only sound...  Replayability: As a consequence of the game's linear storyline, multiple playthroughs are not of interest. Once you have played through the game once, you have seen most of the content there is.   Conclusion: Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a unique first person horror game driven by its compelling story and simple gameplay. Experience the intense and thrilling game equipped with only a lantern and your courage and uncover the dark secrets of Castle Brennenburg.   Recommendable: 10/10

The infamous Amnesia. Driven by a dark and twisted storyline, backed by a soundtrack that is bound to give you the chills, Amnesia is everything you could ask for in a horror game.  Introduction: Amnesia is a first person survival horror game set in a dark and mysterious castle environment. The plot takes place in 1893 where a young man from London, Daniel, finds himself awakened in the great halls of the Prussian Brennenburg Castle with no recollections of himself, his past or his current purpose. The only objects that guide Daniel in his journey are hand-written notes that he has written to himself, such as the one he finds in the beginning of the game.   Controls and Gameplay: The most powerful feature in the game is the absence of items, such as weapons and armor. You are alone and defenseless. Only equipped with a lantern, run by a limited supply of fuel, your goal is to explore and uncover the dark secrets of castle Brenneburg. This is a core feature of the game, as it makes your journey through the castle perilous and terrifying.  Aside from the traditional health bar, your character has a sanity meter. Sanity is reduced if you spend too much time in the dark, and loss of sanity will progressively make your screen indistinct and blurry.   Puzzles and other obstructions are also present in the game. They are, however, not difficult and are sometimes a more than welcome 'time-out' in the intense horror, while at other times they participate in making the game more hectic and intense.   In terms of control, they are working as intended and do not obstruct the player in his quest through the dark.  Graphics: The graphics in the game are slightly dated. This is not a huge minus, as the graphics actually enhance the intense sensation of dread that is omnipresent in the game.   Sound: The soundtrack subliminally emphasizes the mood of the game. It intensifies frightening moments and sooths you in safe zones. It sometimes disappears completely, leaving your character's frantically beating heart as the only sound...  Replayability: As a consequence of the game's linear storyline, multiple playthroughs are not of interest. Once you have played through the game once, you have seen most of the content there is.   Conclusion: Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a unique first person horror game driven by its compelling story and simple gameplay. Experience the intense and thrilling game equipped with only a lantern and your courage and uncover the dark secrets of Castle Brennenburg.   Recommendable: 10/10

I wanted to write a review for Amnesia for such a long time...   I remember that I started playing it with my boyfriend (playing on separate computers but trying to complete the game at the same time). It's not a graphic explicit game; the blood and violence from recent horror games can't compete with the soundtrack and audio effects of Amnesia (the wind hitting the glass windows, the sound of the damn monster aproaching you and hearing your character heavily breathing while the sanity is getting low). These combined with the horror but rather exciting atmosphere made it hard for me to keep up with my boyfriend throughout the whole game. I found myself terrified from the very first minutes and scared to even move around.  'What did I just hear? Was that the sound of a monster? Oh God, is he coming? Don't look behind that damn corner!' I was too scared to play but too intrigued to quit + that if you have good headphones you get cold shivers down the spine.  There is also some sort of psychology behind the fear that this games spreads because you find yourself illustrated as Daniel, a guy who does not (and can not) carry a gun or fight the shadows that follow him. All you can do is run, hide, observe and eventually try to escape but even without wanting you will start being emotionally involved with every note and clue that you find. The story is beautiful and shocking, it becomes more than just a video game. The disturbing environment, the rooms and the darkness... it feels like you explore inside of the main character's soul.   It's a piece of art and probably the best horror game that I ever played, the only one that managed to keep me in front of the screen without jump scares and without too much blood. I strongly recommend it, it's something that everyone in love with video games has to play. I had difficulties sleeping a few weeks after finishing it, but that was because of the open ending that left me thinking and made me question stuff about humanity and life, because yes, it is more than just a horror game. It was made by people with brilliant minds and I consider it an inspiration as long as it makes you question yourself even after finishing the game.

Its a game that gets around and has made quite a name for itself, rightly so - Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of the most gripping, puzzling and horrifying experiences I have ever confronted; and I say confront because this games needs to be confronted, not played. I'll get this out of the way now, this is a First-Person Horror Adventure game, with elements of puzzle and survival, I would say Horror-Survival, but this is an adventure, by far.  WARNING: This article DOES contain some mild spoilers.  TDD is set in 1799, you take on the role of Daniel, a young man who's found himself inside the belly of a ghostly castle. The moment you are brought into the game you are greeted by a brilliant atmosphere, which lasts throughout the entire game, complete with ambient sound effects, enough light to look around, and a few rooms to find your way around the controls. This allows newbies to get a feel for the game first, to play around with controls and to explore a little bit. The controls in this game are fairly simple, and there's nothing that isn't needed or not included.   There's the basic WASD movement, there's a lean feature, which helps peak around corners and explore creaks and crannies. But what truly felt authentic about this game is the how you control the mouse, and what part it plays in the game's mechanics. The majority of doors, objects and drawers can be opened, closed, pushed and pulled all at the movement of the mouse. Want to slowly pull a door open a millimeter without making any sound and hope that a lumbering gammon monster doesn't take a bite out of your face? Click on the door and gently pull your mouse in the same motion as you would slowly opening a door a millimeter without making any sound? Pull your mouse back in that careful motion, want to desperately drag a large crate in front of a suspicious door? Click on that crate, and pull with all your virtual might. This is a point for immersion, and there are many more to come.  As you progress through castle Brennenberg, you slowly begin to unfold the story and characters with help from the flashback-like narration, and several notes found around the castle, this is such a great way to unfold the story as you do it yourself. By entering special places, diaries will be found flashbacks will occur, hallucinations will taunt and sounds of your past self talking being to alert you of the darkness this castle has to reveal (not a pun on the incessant lack of light in this game, but that's one of the prime features). For the first few parts of this fairly short-ish game, it's mostly an exploration, puzzle point and click.   But, despite not having any direct horror, you're constantly on edge. The ambient sounds and vibe keep you frequently checking over your shoulder, you are never safe in this game. This leads me onto my next love of this game. You are defenseless. What's that? Defenseless? A horror-survival FPS with no weapons? Damn right. In this, you've got nothing but your handy lantern, which runs of scarce amounts of oil, scattered around the castle. Encounter a ghoulie? You've got to use your wits. You need to think fast, run as fast as your invisible legs can carry you, or hide in the next room, barricade the door and hide in the closet sucking your thumb. It's a thousand times more thrilling than blasting them away with a Plasma Cutter (I hope some people pick up on this reference).   And speaking of hiding, there's a lovely little system called sanity; Daniel being an insane, ill-mouthed, bumbling psychopath has a severe case of nyctophobia and a surprising dislike for monster with their jaws stapled to their nipples. The sanity meter is a good and bad thing about this game; it discourages you to look at the monsters and to try and solve puzzles, because if in the dark too long or staring at a monster's rear for too long causes visual and audible distortion. This can be scary or sometimes even annoying, there is a crackling, ringing sound when I'm trying to hide and when running around in the dark holding a bucket, it doesn't help when my screen decided to go into an itunes visualizer.  When it comes to horror, this game delivers. This isn't a game with cheap, pop-ups of scary faces, this is more of a tense, 'What's around this corner?' 'What was that noise?' and 'Oh my god I'm being chased by a skinny deformed human with a machete for an arm'. It covers every bit of horror in the different stages of the game, which also links into the perfect level design for TDD.   There's the exploration, carry one puzzle piece through a dark, hollow hallway to another while avoiding the patrolling monster. There's the platform like jumping level, where you have to stay out of the water, or have your feet nibbled off by the invisible ghoul who seems to have two working legs but can't reach up to claw at your toes. And then there's the stealthy, corner to corner, throw at hammer at the wall distraction type of level. There's lots of strategic thinking involved in this game, and how you execute an objective is purely up to you.  Pros: Disturbingly immersive, beautifully narrated and spine-chillingly creepy. Cons: Slightly goofy voice acting, and one or two bugs encountered with the physics engine.   All in all this is nothing short of a masterpiece. A scary-puzzle game at heart, wrapped together in a bow of interesting storytelling, interactive environment and fantastic ambiance.  Play this one with headphones on and lights off. You'll thank me later.  No overall score because why should a complex opinion be represented numerically, but some people came here only for the numbers, so, 9.5/10. Jackass.

What’s interesting about Amnesia is that it eschews most conventional notions associated with the horror genre and manages to transcend other similar games in delivering an immersive and unparalleled experience. Arbitrary and cheap frights are totally absent. It does Lovecraft in the purest sense; it understands that the imagined far outweighs the known in its psychological punch, which in Amnesia’s case is achieved through stellar environment and audio design. But it is the removal of weapons and consequently combat that introduces a wholly new dynamic and therein lies Amnesia’s brilliance. What the game is capable is elevated to an entirely new level. It is undoubtedly creative, original and works flawlessly alongside Lovecraftian themes hinted at. It is a shining example of what the first-person genre, outside of shooting, can achieve on an experiential level.

The atmosphere is certainly top notch, and I'm not denying that alot of effort was put into that aspect of the game. The game is genuinely creepy in certain moments, especially the beginning. But, much else is poorly done in my opinion. It boils down to simply walking around doing tedious puzzles with the ocasional monster runin, where you resort to the same routine every single time: running away, briefly waiting for it to go away and then continuing pulling levers. It's also burdened by the tedious insanity mechanic where once the game decies 'you are now scared', you have to stare at a lamp for 10 seconds or the protagnist will start having asthma attacks. I don't like a game telling me I'm scared, it's annoying and takes me out of the experience.  The game has little challenge outside of these puzzles as you practically trip over tinderboxes and oil. Combine these two and there is little to no challenge, just tedium. Finishing the game, I had 101 tinderboxes and 26 oil refills. I definitely prefer when horror games are more restrictive in resources, I feel it adds more tension. There's also the problem of deaths being entirely meaningless. In fact, the enemy may even not appear upon respawn - in other words, the game rewards you for dying by taking away the enemy that killed you.  I loved the lore. Was very interesting, to the point where I would risk resources just to explore and learn more about the environment I found myself in.  I applaud the unique experience, but considering how it spawned the trend of boring horror games where you can't fight back I certainly coould've done without this one. The ending is anticlimactic and the 'good' ending I got moreso than any of the 'bad' ones. If you're itching to try it, I would suggest picking it up on a sale.   - Suspense climaxes at the very beginning of the game - very well done, but blows steam too fast - Far too liberal in handing out resources - Little/no challenge - Tedious at times  + Great atmosphere + Good Lore + No over-reliance on jumpscares + Unique concept (at the time)    Edit 12/23/16: I finally got around to trying a very similar game, outlast. This one is far better between the two famed horror titles, I'll give it that much.

The folks at Frictional Games are huge fans of H.P. Lovecraft, and their games draw heavily from his works. They refined the true Horror game formula through the Penumbra series. Amnesia pulls together everything they did right, trims out the fat, and makes for a terrifying experience of nightmarish psychological horror. Amnesia is more than a game, it's an experiance. A terrifying and disturbing experience that will last with you long before you put the game down.  I'm someone who loves horror and all that is creepy, I'm someone who can calmly play any Resident Evil or Silent Hill game. But with Amnesia, I don't have that option.   See, with other horror games, you're given weapons, a way to defend yourself. In Amnesia, the only weapon you have is your mind. That's right, there's not a single weapon in the game, and this is a great thing. With no way to defend yourself, all you can do is run and hide and hope that monster walks past the room where you're hiding in. This captures nothing but pure terror.   Monsters don't just hear you and see you, they can find you based on your sanity level. Staying too long in the dark or looking at disturbing things will drain your sanity. To regain it, you must progress and stay in well lit areas, which are often hard to come by in Amnesia. It goes without saying that you should do everything in your power to keep your sanity level up, or else everything is harder to do, even to tell whether that noise you heard is a monster, or just a product of your imagination.   In addition to the terror aspect of Amnesia, there is also an interesting story and detailed areas to explore, that capture the dark feel of the game. Also, there are custom stories for this game, that are mods created by users that add to the playability to Amnesia. Even after you beat Amnesia, there is more to play with these custom stories.   So, the question is, should you buy this game? Yes, absolutly. At a sale? If you wanna wait and save a little money, sure, but I recommend getting this game even at full price. Whether you're familiar with horror, or this is your first horror game, it has something to offer you, an unforgettable experience.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent [Steam]: 7.7/10 Not my first choice for something to bust my Steam cherry, but it was free one day so you know I'm going to take advantage of it. It took quite some time to get this game to work. I don't want to have the app take up the entire screen so I wouldn't be able to see my messages and such, and if I dared to exit the game it would freeze the computer. Finally, after fixing the issue, I started the game. Immediately after starting the game, it told me that I should take every measure possible to immerse myself in the world it creates (turning off the lights, etc.), but I quickly learned that this was a pointless measure to take because of how immersive the game is despite the conditions that surround me. Immersion is important for Amnesia because it is a plot dependent horror game, and unlike Five Nights at Freddy's, this game doesn't just throw jumpscares at you expecting you to be satisfied. It's genuine horror, the kind that makes you expect something to be behind you whenever you turn around. I suppose evidence of the game's competence in this area can be proven simply by looking at the monsters. Look up a picture of 'The Gatherers' and tell me they don't look ♥♥♥♥ing stupid. No way would anyone be scared of it on its own. However, thanks to the musical score and the overall atmosphere of the world, these things will leave you terrified. There is a blatant 'issue' I suppose I'll address. You're supposed to hide from these things and wait until they leave you alone, but if you let them kill you, 9 times out of 10, they won't be there the next time you enter the area they were in before your death. Considering the fact that you don't have limited lives, you can cheat the system and basically just kill yourself and pass on through. I submit to you that this is a good thing, however. The game is not shy of telling you that it is trying to be more immersive than, for lack of a better word, 'fun', and eliminating some hardships certain people will have at certain points was a good move for them on that part, because it allows everyone, no matter the skill level, to experience the full length of the game. In the matter of exploiting this mechanic to pass through the game quicker, that's more about punishing yourself really. You'd have to deliberately make an honest attempt to get killed by these things to bypass them, and if you do that you're cheating yourself out of the terror and the strategy from hiding from them. There are quite a lot of puzzles in this game, and they're pretty great for the most part. Some of them are skill based, and others rely on intuition. There are some, however, that are not very clear as to what you need to do, in fact there was a audio glitch that screwed me up at one point. I've also heard a complaint that a puzzle won't let you proceed until you do the puzzle incorrectly, but I did not have the displeasure of that experience. The plot is somewhat interesting. I don't believe I've heard anything like it before, and I couldn't wait to see how it unraveled. The voice actors did a marvelous job for the most part. There were a couple of lines that actually made me laugh because there were so poorly done, but those were only few. This game does an exceptionally good job with what it was determined to do: be a terrifying and immersive experience. Horror games and movies don't really affect me easily, and while I didn't get too scared, I definitely was unnerved by being chased by the various monsters. It's no longer free, but I can safely say that it's worth the 20 dollar asking price. The game will run you to about 10 hours by the way.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent  is arguably the best psychological horror game ever created.  The story begins as the protagonist, a young man named Daniel, awakens, bereft of memories, in what appears to be a gloomy medieval castle. The player will quickly discover a Memento-style note to self, exposing that Daniel himself has wiped his memories, giving him a mission to 'put things right' by finding someone called Alexander and killing him, and warning him that he is being followed by 'a living nightmare.'  Stage set, the player is set adrift to explore the vast, creepy, run-down castle. The game makes excellent use of darkness as a mechanism to balance tension: when the player remains in the dark for too long, Daniel begins to be frightened, which eventually damages his sanity àla Call of Cthulhu. However, the only two sources of illumination, tinderboxes for lighting stationary items such as candles and torches, and an oil-devouring lantern Daniel carries with him, both leave the player exposed and are only available in limited supply. Therefore, much of the game is a constant conflict between shivering in the murky blackness and taking brief refuge in temporary light.  Advancement is achieved via exploration, unveiling pieces of Daniel's forgotten past, and solving strongly thematic puzzles: repairing decrepit machinery or creating alchemical concoctions. These puzzles, while reinforcing the player's immersion, also force her to scrounge the darkest, most forlorn corners of the vast, decaying edifice for tools, parts, and ingredients, collecting mementos, letters, and fragments of journal entries along the way.  The visual and aural ambience blend perfectly to submerge the player in her surroundings: Daniel shakes, breathes heavily, and suffers from distorted vision when he's frightened; the building creaks and groans as Daniel traverses its dusty corridors; and nameless beings emit unspeakable utterances, hopefully in the distance.  There are a number of hostile beings lurking in the darkness - not many, but given that the only defenses available to Daniel are hiding in the gloom or running desperately for his life, the prospect of a horrifying demise looming suddenly out of the shadows is sufficient motivation to keep the player creeping nervously from room to room, afraid to make a noise or light a lamp.  The Dark Descent clearly draws inspiration, in terms of subject matter, psychological application of horrific elements, and malleability of the player's sanity and overall mental state, from the works of H.P. Lovecraft - in turn, it breathes new life into Lovecraft's concepts by exposing them to new generations via a new medium nearly a century later.  For fans of modern psychological horror, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a  must-play  - the epitome of the genre. For newcomers, it would be difficult to find a better starting point.  I nominated this game for the 'Test of Time' award in the 2016 Steam Awards.

The very same movement that can alert your foes to where you are and this pervasive sense that you are constantly in danger. Combined with limited supplies for lighting your dim environments it has all the right ingredients for leaving a lasting impression.  Its length manages to keep the game from feeling too long and not too short, but perhaps does start to wane its hook into you as it goes on. There are some great moments and set-pieces, aided with headphones and no lighting apart from the thin glare off your monitor, that will stick with you for some time, but these are punctuated by fairly simple puzzles. The 'but' comes from the fact that whilst they never really break the tense feeling established, as the game goes on you realise that the puzzles are essentially safe environments and no matter how long you spend in (most of) them, you're probably going to be safe from attack.  Similarly, the first time you get a game over, the scare factor immediately drops; the game reminds you that it's a game and takes you right out of the atmosphere it has carefully constructed. Generally dying once will allow you to piece together what you did wrong and move onto the next area, where the fear will be built back up again, but it really decreases the sense of dread from the imposing and grotesque things hunting for you when you realise that they're just common video game enemies with the advantage of you not being able to defend yourself.  That said, these moments are few and far between and safely overridden by those couple of minutes where you catch sight of an enemy who locks eyes on you and you hastily try to flee and find somewhere, anywhere, desperately to keep you safe. And as you wait in the darkness for the footsteps to get close, right on top of you even and then to fade away with distance, you turn your light back on and realise that you were lucky that time, but maybe the next...  It's those moments joined with some tight pacing and a great atmosphere that make this a really fun, really enjoyable experience, but perhaps only for the one playthrough.

If you yourself are still someone lucky enough to know little about the game and are interested in checking it out, please, by all means, do so!  I did take a swipe there at custom stories but actually one of the best things about this game is the custom story community. The Frictional forums are a mostly friendly lot while still unafraid of offering criticism to the various people offering up their custom stories (and there are some now-overdone cliches that run through the lesser stories they, and anyone else with sense would have low tolerance for - read up on teleporting naked guy jumpscares to see what I mean). It's a good place to get feedback and also help on how to use the game's editors for models, levels, textures and so on for making custom stories. ModDB is also a good place to go to look for the better stories (from what I've seen of the most highly rated stories their user base has pretty good standards). It's great since once you're done with the main game there's a solid variety of other stuff, some full conversions, some games almost as long if not longer than the actual game itself, you'll get a good amount of hours from booting up this game. While not nearly as robust as say the Half-Life 2 / Source mod scene (then again what is?) this is up there. If you want to make your own stories you can download a lot of custom-created stuff to use for a custom story, including a flashlight to replace the lantern if you're putting your game in a modern setting, plus the importing of a ton of textures and models from the Penumbra games, and recently Frictional offering A Machine for Pigs stuff to import too, currently in testing stage.   Oh yeah and this version includes the extra side story Justine, which many of you may know, so that's a nice bonus too. I'm not personally fond of Justine, due to some annoying puzzles and the fact that there's no save function at all (it isn't a long game, no, but it's easy enough to die a few places and starting the whole thing all over is aggravating). This game has a lot of really good ideas, and most of them work as intended. I found it to be rather scary, although some times not for the reason that might have been intended. Wandering a dark hallway, trying to find the item you need to solve a puzzle or to advance, might sound simple enough, but the fact that the darkness is your enemy, as well the Servants, really makes you have to think about what is the better idea. You can either run the risk of an enemy seeing you, or you can wander in the darkness and let your sanity drop, which may also lead to your death. It can be a hard choice at times, and you won't always make the right decision, but luckily there are enough checkpoints that you won't lose much progress if you lose all your sanity or health. The Servants themselves are freaky up close, although if you are seeing them up close, you are probably going to die anyway. And the fact that even looking at them drops your character's sanity means you mostly have to rely on hearing them, which is absolutely terrifying.  But of course, not everything works in this game. The puzzles are sometimes really tricky, as the game does next to nothing at times to give you a hint as to what you are supposed to be looking for, or what can be used on what and when. It usually is not a problem, but at times you might end up scratching your head, looking at your objective and inventory, trying to figure out how the items you have will get you to your objective. I had it happen a few times, but never enough that I got stuck for hours on end. Also, having health and health items on this game feels useless since you'll usually die in a hit or two anyway, so there really does not seem to be much point in having it. The biggest problem I found with the game is when it comes to escaping enemies. If I am spotted, even if I run and hide in the darkness three rooms away from where I was spotted, the Servants still seemed to be able to find me every time. They are faster than the character, so running can be hard if you are spotted and you're not near a doorway to run in to. I only ever managed to get away from any enemy once: I was killed every other time. Maybe I was just doing something wrong, but it was annoying nonetheless. Still, it only becomes a problem if you get spotted, so just be careful and it will never come up.

Amnesia  — in which you play as an amnesiac named Daniel as he stumbles through a generic Prussian castle filled with generic horror-genre tropes — is one of the most boring and predictable games I’ve played in years.  I’m an absolute sh*tbag. I nearly  cried  playing through  Thief: Deadly Shadows ’ Shalebridge Cradle. I have screamed my lungs out playing  Resident Evil 4  for God’s sake. I thought  Amnesia  would be a game I would never be able to finish due to paralyzing fear. But, much to my disappointment, I never once felt anything close to fear, terror, or panic. When I wasn’t sighing with boredom, I was rolling my eyes at, frankly, childish attempts to frighten me.  The game follows a very basic pattern: You enter a new area and look for an object to take or puzzle to solve, at which point an enemy spawns in. You then hide for a minute or so, the enemy despawns, and you leave. The only time this pattern changes during the game’s 7–8 hour play-time is during one section in a flooded tunnel which is a simple platforming challenge. The game is not scary; it’s tedious.  The problem with this predictability is that you always know when you are safe and when you are less safe. There’s no sense of being stalked, no sense of lurking danger, no paranoia. You know when an enemy exists in the area and when they don’t, through design and the obvious leitmotif. There’s no tension, and, consequently, no atmosphere, without which there is no horror.  At first, the idea of not being able to fight back against the monsters seems like a good one, but the implementation is tragic. The disfigured creatures — which are genuinely freakish and creepy — can move faster than Daniel and drive him insane if he looks directly at them. The monsters only work when they are far away, giving you time to find a hiding place; the game  can’t  spawn one too close to you, because to do so would be an instant game over. Most areas in the game are long, narrow corridors leading to dead ends, so monster encounters involve hiding in a dark corner until the monster despawns once it’s out of sight.  That’s it. That’s the entire game. As long as you don’t run directly at the monsters, you are never in any danger, and every encounter plays out in the  exact same way . For eight hours.  The game tries its best to make this scary by using sanity effects, which manifest as screen-blur and a laggy mouse when Daniel is scared. These effects debilitate you in the most frustrating manner, since you can barely see or move, and are near constant. Being in the dark drives Daniel insane, as does looking at enemies. But the only way to hide from enemies is to crouch in the dark, so you go insane no matter what. You  can  light candles and torches to create sanity-giving light, but the monsters will find you more easily and you have fewer places to hide. So, basically, you’re going to play this game like you’re walking in a heatwave with dodgy controls. This is annoying, not scary.  It’s a shame, too, because the game is pretty when the screen is stable. Castle Brennenburg is interesting enough to walk around and could have been a good setting if there was any kind of atmosphere whatsoever. It’s also nice to have physics-based object manipulation. Small things, like opening a desk drawer and seeing a cylindrical tinderbox roll around, are simply satisfying, and it’s fun throwing chairs and rocks around, even if there is no reason to.  I was left with the impression that  Amnesia  would work better as a  Myst -esque puzzle game. If Daniel simply explored a creepy castle, reading creepy notes detailing creepy things that happened there, all the while solving puzzles that make use of those notes, as well as the object physics, I would have had a wonderful time. The mistake it makes is trying to be a horror game. Despite all the praise heaped on it for that exact reason,  Amnesia  is bad at being scary.  The game asks you to immerse yourself in the world rather than focus on ‘winning’, but everything is so obviously contrived that immersion is all but impossible. Being so bored, I found myself wondering why Daniel was afraid of the dark when it is the safest place to go, and whether Frictional know what a tinder box actually is.  Amnesia  strives for psychological horror, but all it does is say ‘Boo,’ exactly when you know it will.
